action_definition.name: run_shell_command
action_definition.description: Run shell commands in a persistent terminal session. Each session_id creates an isolated shell environment that persists between calls.

parameter.description: The command to execute. To interrupt a running command, send the literal string "^C" (caret + uppercase C).

Set to true when sending input to a process that is already running in the terminal (e.g., responding to a password prompt, or sending data to an interactive program). When false (default), the command starts a new execution. If the session is busy with a running command and this is false, you will get an error.
Maximum seconds to wait for command completion. If exceeded, the command continues running in background and you get a "running" status. Default: 30 seconds.

Unique identifier for the terminal session. Use different session_ids to run commands in parallel! For example, use "scan1" for a long-running nmap scan, "main" for quick commands, and "exploit" for exploitation. Each session_id creates a completely isolated shell. Default: your agent ID.
If true, sends the command without a trailing newline (useful for TUI interaction).

returns.description: Result containing: content (stdout), status ("completed" or "running"), exit_code (integer or null if running), terminal_id, and error (if any).

usage_notes.note: PARALLEL SESSIONS: To run long commands (nmap, ffuf, gobuster) without blocking, use a dedicated session_id like "scan". Then use your default session for other work.
INTERRUPT BLOCKING COMMANDS: If a session is busy, send command="^C" to interrupt it. This sends Ctrl+C to the running process.
INTERACT WITH RUNNING PROCESS: Use require_input=true to send input to an already-running process (e.g., password prompts, interactive menus).
SESSION IS BUSY ERROR: This means a command is still running in that session. Either: (1) wait for it, (2) send "^C" to interrupt, or (3) use a different session_id.
